Relax. Let the framework do the heavy lifting.

Lido - A lightweight (10kb) semantic framework for SASS. Configure styles easily and spend less time creating bloated, custom code.

Download v0.1.0Documentation

What can Lido do for you?

The Grid

A 12-column, lightweight grid to help you quickly build responsive websites. Leave the default settings or modify the configration settings to test grid width, gutters, breakpoints, etc.

Each column is contained within rows, which are contained within a container. The container is set to a maximum width of 960px by default.

.col-12
.col-6
.col-6
.col-4
.col-8
.col-10
.col-2
<div class="container">
	<div class="row">
			<div class="col-12">
					<div class="demo">.col-12</div>
			</div>
			<div class="col-6">
					<div class="demo">.col-6</div>
			</div>
			<div class="col-6">
					<div class="demo">.col-6</div>
			</div>
			<div class="col-4">
					<div class="demo">.col-4</div>
			</div>
			<div class="col-8">
					<div class="demo">.col-8</div>
			</div>
			<div class="col-10">
					<div class="demo">.col-10</div>
			</div>
			<div class="col-2">
					<div class="demo">.col-2</div>
			</div>
	</div>
</div>

Typography

Lido uses Muli, from Google Fonts, as a default typeface. The font size for semantic elements is based on rem units, therefore every item can be responsively-sized by targeting only a single property.

To simplify sizing, Lido is configured to make sure 1rem = 10px out-of-the-box, but can easily be configured with a single change.

Heading 1

Heading 2

Heading 3

Heading 4

Heading 5
Heading 6

This is normal paragraph text. This is Bold Text, and This is Italic Text

This is Small Text

This is a Blockquote

<h1>Heading 1</h1>
<h2>Heading 2</h2>
 <h3>Heading 3</h3>
 <h4>Heading 4</h4>
 <h5>Heading 5</h5>
 <h6>Heading 6</h6>
 <p>This is normal paragraph text. <strong>This is Bold Text, </strong>and <em>This is Italic Text</em></p>
 <p>
  <small>This is Small Text</small>
 </p>
 <p>
   <blockquote>This is a Blockquote</blockquote>
 </p>

Buttons

Button Styles

Included in Lido are several styles of buttons — each with it's own semantic purpose.

<button class="button button--default" type="button">Default</button>
<button class="button button--primary" type="button">Primary</button>
<button class="button button--success" type="button">Success</button>
<button class="button button--danger" type="button">Danger</button>
<button class="button button--warning" type="button">Warning</button>
<button class="button button--info" type="button">Info</button>
Button Modifiers

Size modifiers are also included to make sure buttons fit with various containers

<button class="button button--primary" type="button">Default Size</button>
<button class="button button--primary button--sm" type="button">Small Size</button>
<button class="button button--primary button--lg" type="button">Large </button>

Tables

The basic styles for tables is simply a border separating the table headers from table data.

#Column 1Column 2
1Item 1Item 2
2Item 1Item 2
3Item 1Item 2
Table Modifiers

Modifiers allow us to create more advanced table styling, such as adding 'dark mode'. You can use as little or as many modifiers as you would like.

Dark Mode with
.table--dark
#Column 1Column 2
1Item 1Item 2
2Item 1Item 2
3Item 1Item 2
Hover Styles with
.table--hover
#Column 1Column 2
1Item 1Item 2
2Item 1Item 2
3Item 1Item 2
Striped Rows with
.table--striped
#Column 1Column 2
1Item 1Item 2
2Item 1Item 2
3Item 1Item 2
All at once with
.table--megazord
#Column 1Column 2
1Item 1Item 2
2Item 1Item 2
3Item 1Item 2
<table class="table--megazord">
 <thead>
   <tr>
     <td scope="col">#</td>
     <th scope="col">Column 1</th>
     <th scope="col">Column 2</th>
   </tr>
 </thead>
 <tbody>
   <tr>
     <th scope="row">1</th>
     <td>Item 1</td>
     <td>Item 2</td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
     <th scope="row">2</th>
     <td>Item 1</td>
     <td>Item 2</td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
     <th scope="row">3</th>
     <td>Item 1</td>
     <td>Item 2</td>
   </tr>
 </tbody>
</table>

Forms

We all can agree that forms and inputs are a pain. Hopefully, these standardized styles make it a bit easier to work with forms.

Text Inputs
This is help text
Inline Radios/Checkboxes
Block Radios/Checkboxes
Select Inputs
<form>
 <div class="form-input">
  <label for="textInput">Text Input</label>
  <input type="text" placeholder="This is a text input" id="textInput"/>
  <small>This is help text</small>
 </div>
 <div class="form-check">
  <input type="radio" name="inlineRadios" id="iRadio1"/>
  <label for="iRadio1">Inline Radio 1</label>
  <input type="radio" name="inlineRadios" id="iRadio2"/>
  <label for="iRadio2">Inline Radio 2</label>
  <input type="radio" name="inlineRadios" id="iRadio3"/>
  <label for="iRadio3">Inline Radio 3</label>
 </div>
 <div class="form-check">
  <fieldset>
   <input type="checkbox" name="blockCheckboxes" id="bCheck1"/>
   <label for="bCheck1">Block Check 1</label>
  </fieldset>
  <fieldset>
   <input type="checkbox" name="blockCheckboxes" id="bCheck2"/>
   <label for="bCheck2">Block Check 2</label>
  </fieldset>
  <fieldset>
   <input type="checkbox" name="blockCheckboxes" id="bCheck3"/>
   <label for="bCheck3">Block Check3</label>
  </fieldset>
 </div>
 <div class="form-input">
  <label for="selectInput">Select</label>
  <select id="selectInput">
   <option>Option 1</option>
   <option>Option 2</option>
   <option>Option 3</option>
  </select>
 </div>
</form>

Lists

Styles for ordered, unordered, and definition lists

Unordered Lists
  • Listed Item #1
  • Listed Item #2
    • Nested Item #1
    • Nested Item #2
  • Listed Item #3
Ordered Lists
  1. Listed Item #1
  2. Listed Item #2
    • Nested Item #1
    • Nested Item #2
  3. Listed Item #3
Definition Lists
Introduction
This the introduction description
Section 1
This the section 1 description
Conclusion
This the conclusion description
<ul>
    <li>Listed Item #1</li>
    <li>Listed Item #2
      <ul>
        <li>Nested Item #1</li>
        <li>Nested Item #2</li>
      </ul>
    </li>
    <li>Listed Item #3</li>
  </ul>
  <ol>
    <li>Listed Item #1</li>
    <li>Listed Item #2
      <ul>
        <li>Nested Item #1</li>
        <li>Nested Item #2</li>
      </ul>
    </li>
    <li>Listed Item #3</li>
  </ol>
  <dl>
    <dt>Introduction</dt>
    <dd>This the introduction description</dd>
    <dt>Section 1</dt>
    <dd>This the section 1 description</dd>
    <dt>Conclusion</dt>
    <dd>This the conclusion description</dd>
  </dl>

Badges

Badges can be used for smaller counts and acts as labeling components. Included in Lido are several styles of badges — each with it's own semantic purpose.

1
2
3
4
5
6
Modifiers
Default
Large
<div class="badge badge--default">1</div>
<div class="badge badge--primary">2</div>
<div class="badge badge--success">3</div>
<div class="badge badge--danger">4</div>
<div class="badge badge--warning">5</div>
<div class="badge badge--info">6</div>
<div class="badge badge--primary">Default</div>
<div class="badge badge--primary badge--lg">Large</div>

Utilities/Helpers

Lido has a number of small utility classes which can be used to style elements on the fly and make your life a whole lot easier.

// Helpers / Utilities
.u-full-width {
  width: 100%;
}
.u-max-full-width {
  max-width: 100%;
}

/* Float text with eg. .u-text--right */
@each $pull in right, left {
  .u-pull--#{$pull} {
    float: #{$pull};
  }
}

/* Align text with eg. .u-text--center */
@each $text-align in right, left, center, justify {
  .u-text--#{$text-align} {
    text-align: #{$text-align};
  }
}

.u-disabled{
  cursor: default;
  opacity: .5;
  pointer-events: none;
}

/* Clear inner floats */
.u-clearfix {
  &:after {
    clear: both;
    content: "";
    display: table;
  }
}

.u-hidden-sm {
  display: none;
}

/* Color text with eg. .u-text--primary
	$states = primary, danger, default, success, warning, info
	*/
.u-text {
	@each $key, $val in $states {
    &--#{$key} {
     color: $val;
    }
  }
}
